qas.question: What school of thought did Berkeley belong to?
What sort of idealist was Descartes?
In what section was Descartes criticized?

plausible_answers.text: to infer the 'I' as an object

qas.question: What does Descartes say is impossible?
What Latin phrase did Kant coin?
When did Locke publish his ideas?

plausible_answers.text: Descartes's Sceptical Idealism and Berkeley's anti-realist strain of Subjective Idealism

qas.question: The 2nd edition merged its ideas with which two forms of thought?

context: The <a3_0>2nd<a3_0/> edition (<a4_0><b7_0>1787<b7_0/><a4_0/>) contained a Refutation of Idealism to distinguish his transcendental idealism from <b8_0>Descartes's <a1_0>Sceptical<a1_0/> Idealism and Berkeley's anti-realist strain of <a0_0>Subjective Idealism<b8_0/><a0_0/>. The section <a2_0>Paralogisms of Pure Reason<a2_0/> is an implicit critique of Descartes' idealism. Kant says that it is not possible <b5_0>to infer the 'I' as an object<b5_0/> (Descartes' <b6_0>cogito ergo sum<b6_0/>) purely from "the spontaneity of thought". Kant focused on ideas drawn from <b9_0>British<b9_0/> philosophers such as Locke, Berkeley and Hume but distinguished his transcendental or critical idealism from previous varieties;
